skill.name: cirq
skill.description: Google quantum computing framework. Use when targeting Google Quantum AI hardware, designing noise-aware circuits, or running quantum characterization experiments. Best for Google hardware, noise modeling, and low-level circuit design. For IBM hardware use qiskit; for quantum ML with autodiff use pennylane; for physics simulations use qutip.
skill.summary: Google quantum computing framework. Use when targeting Google Quantum AI hardware, designing noise-a...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All 324 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. This is a pure documentation skill containing markdown files with Python code examples for Google's Cirq quantum computing library. The scanner triggered on documentation patterns (backtick code blocks, quantum gate names like CNOT/CZ, measurement key parameters) that it misinterpreted as security issues. No executable code, network connections, credential exfiltration, or malicious patterns exist. The skill is safe for publishing.

content.user_title: Work with Google's Cirq quantum computing framework
content.value_statement: Design and simulate quantum circuits using Google's Cirq framework. This skill provides comprehensive documentation for building quantum circuits, noise modeling, hardware integration, and running experiments on quantum computers and simulators.
actual_capabilities: Build quantum circuits with gates, qubits, measurements, and custom operations
Simulate quantum circuits with state vector, density matrix, and noisy simulators
Model noise channels, depolarizing errors, and run characterization experiments
Integrate with Google Quantum AI, IonQ, Azure Quantum, and other providers
Optimize and transform circuits for specific hardware constraints
Run parameter sweeps and variational algorithms for quantum research
limitations: Does not provide actual quantum hardware access (requires separate provider accounts)
Simulation scales exponentially with qubit count (practical limit around 30-40 qubits)
Hardware execution time and availability depends on external quantum computing providers
Error mitigation techniques require additional configuration and may not eliminate all errors

use_cases.title: Design quantum experiments
use_cases.description: Design and simulate experiments with parameterized circuits, noise models, and data collection for quantum research publications.

use_cases.title: Build quantum algorithms
use_cases.description: Implement quantum algorithms like VQE, QAOA, and QPE using Cirq's circuit building and transformation framework.

use_cases.title: Target quantum processors
use_cases.description: Compile and optimize circuits for specific quantum processors from Google, IonQ, Azure, and other providers.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Circuit
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a Bell state circuit with Cirq using two qubits, a Hadamard gate, and CNOT gate with measurement.

prompt_templates.title: Noisy Simulation
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me add depolarizing noise to a quantum circuit and run noisy simulations to analyze error impact.

prompt_templates.title: Hardware Execution
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I configure Cirq to run circuits on Google Quantum AI hardware and select the best qubits based on calibration data?

prompt_templates.title: Circuit Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Transform my circuit to use only the native gateset for a specific quantum processor and reduce circuit depth.

output_examples.input: Create a quantum circuit that creates a GHZ state with 3 qubits and measures all qubits.
output: Here's how to create a GHZ (Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger) state with 3 qubits:
â€¢ Use cirq.LineQubit to create 3 qubits
â€¢ Apply Hadamard to first qubit to create superposition
â€¢ Apply CNOT gates to entangle all qubits in a chain
â€¢ Measure all qubits with a descriptive key
The circuit creates the state |000âŸ© + |111âŸ©/âˆš2, demonstrating genuine 3-qubit entanglement.

best_practices: Start with simulators before running on expensive quantum hardware time
Use circuit optimization transformers to reduce depth before hardware execution
Label measurements with descriptive keys for easier result analysis
Save experiment results immediately after hardware runs to prevent data loss
anti_patterns: Running complex circuits without first validating on simulators
Ignoring device topology constraints when selecting qubits
Skipping noise characterization before error mitigation
Not using qubit calibration data for hardware qubit selection

faq.question: What is Cirq?
faq.answer: Cirq is Google's open-source Python library for designing, simulating, and running quantum circuits on quantum computers and simulators.

faq.question: How does Cirq differ from Qiskit?
faq.answer: Cirq is optimized for Google's quantum hardware and offers low-level circuit design, while Qiskit is designed for IBM hardware with higher-level abstractions.

faq.question: Can Cirq run on real quantum computers?
faq.answer: Yes, Cirq supports multiple quantum hardware providers including Google Quantum AI, IonQ, Azure Quantum, AQT, and Pasqal with appropriate API access.

faq.question: What simulators does Cirq support?
faq.answer: Cirq provides state vector simulation, density matrix simulation, and the Quantum Virtual Machine (QVM) for various simulation needs.

faq.question: How many qubits can Cirq simulate?
faq.answer: State vector simulation scales as 2^n, making 30-40 qubits practical on modern hardware. Density matrix scales as 4^n with higher memory requirements.

faq.question: What is noise modeling in Cirq?
faq.answer: Cirq allows adding noise channels like depolarizing, amplitude damping, and phase damping to circuits for simulating realistic quantum computer behavior.
